dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Settled on a fork of the Yamhill River in the Pacific Northwest rests the small railway city of MILL VALLEY. All is quiet, save for the clacking of a lone train. SERIES OF OPENING SHOTS of a TOWN IN DECLINE:

dialogues.speaker: ON MAIN STREET
dialogues.text: Outside MILL VALLEY PAWN SHOP, an OLD TIMER lowers the AMERICAN FLAG. A RECORD SHOP next door is already BOARDED Super: MILL VALLEY, OCT 31st, 1968. A DISK JOCKEY who sounds like he is battling throat cance cuts through the doleful monotony of Americana --

dialogues.speaker: DISK JOCKEY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Dig yourself out of the grave, Mill Valley, ‘cause this could be our last Halloween...

dialogues.speaker: ON HOUSE
dialogues.text: A MOTHER places a JACK-O-LANTERN on her porch -- then see her “VOTE NIXON ‘68” YARD SIGN has been vandalized. The ‘ has been turned into a swastika. Mortified, she removes i

dialogues.speaker: ON UNFINISHED OVERPASS
dialogues.text: CONSTRUCTION WORKERS laugh as they pack up for the day beneath an unfinished SPRAWLING RAISED HIGHWAY.

dialogues.speaker: DISK JOCKEY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...When that giant monstrosity is finally built, they may as well turn the knife, cause the rest of the world is gonna pass us by... A SULLEN MAN with the name OREN embroidered on his covera drifts away from the pack to load his tools in his pick-u

dialogues.speaker: ON GRAVEYARD
dialogues.text: STELLA MICHAELS (15), meek with thick black specs that ar easy to hide behind, reads a book (TRUE GRIT, Portis) whi taking a bite of a sandwich in front of a GRAVESTONE on t anniversary of her mother’s death. DINAH B. MICHAELS Apr 1921 - Oct 31 1958.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you got me. To say what I wanna say, and play what I wanna play... The Sun sets--- Stella uses an early POLAROID camera to photograph a STONE SKULL on a gravestone, then grabs her to leave.

dialogues.speaker: DISK JOCKEY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: So you be careful out there tonight - cause when the sun goes down... It’s the Season of the Witch. A plucky GUITAR RIFF begins. It’s coupled with a BLUESY B LINE. The slow groove of Donovan’s “Season of the Witch” we continue our OPENING SEQUENCE:

dialogues.speaker: ON NEIGHBORHOOD STREET
dialogues.text: Cowboys, princesses and pirates collect their annual haul sweets on a suburban street from a bygone era. A CLOSED CINEMA: On its dilapidated marquee a crumbling s announces TH HEART IS A ONELY HUNT R. The cinema may be closed, but the street is alive: Childr keep their candy bags close as -- a 68’ BLUE BONNEVILLE s down the street like a shark on the prowl. KURT MILNER (18) drives with a sucker in his mouth. His c filled with LETTERMANS chugging Schlitz, looking for trou Donovan's swagger-filled lyrics kick in --

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: “When I look out my window... Many sights to see....” DEPUTY HOBBS (20s) looks out the window of his idle PATRO CRUISER. As he pets his dog TRIGGER, he motions to Kurt t keep it moving. They do.

dialogues.speaker: IN STEINBERG HOUSEHOLD
dialogues.text: THE STEINBERGS (married, bored, him yawning, her, sewing costume) watch TV. ON it: Nixon.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: I'll take only a minute. I hada very good briefing by Secretary Rusk this morning up at New York. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then I just went over and had a half hour with the General and he’s- it’s the longest visit he had. He just looks great. ALICE STEINBERG (17) cruises by in a slip and her bouffan already done up, carrying swaths of fabric. She heads upstairs and goes by -- The bathroom -- Then does a double take, retraces her steps: There. Kneel before the toilet, is CHUCK STEINBERG (14), a scamp with large mouth that looks ill-placed on his unusually-small

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing? The answer? He’s angling for a turd with a small aquarium fish net.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Little privacy please! Chuck slams the bathroom door in his sister’s face.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: “And when I look in my window... So many different people to be.”

dialogues.speaker: IN HILDERBRANDT HOUSEHOLD
dialogues.text: AUGGIE HILDERBRANDT (15), excessively tall with long hair a mopey face, dons a Pierrot costume with black button-ba down a white, silk front.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: Mom. It's fine.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HILDERBRANDT
dialogues.text: It’s loose in the crotch. He buries his mortification as she measures his inseam an sticks him with pins.

dialogues.speaker: IN MICHAELS HOUSEHOLD
dialogues.text: OREN MICHAELS, the sullen man from the construction site, pops open another beer and stares at a TV that isn’t on. Stella mournfully glances from the threshold of the bathr fresh out of the shower and wrapped in a towel. She shuts door. Her father pays no attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A drawer is opened. Stella’s hand digs through the clutte expose -- a STRAIGHT RAZOR gleans under a mishmash of MAK Stella stares into the mirror. Her body is gaunt, almost skeletal. A sadness in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: “That it's strange... So strange.” She lifts her chin, then -- slits her throat, WITH A LINE BLACK FACE PAINT. The beginnings of a Halloween costume.

dialogues.speaker: ON MORALES PAINT-CHIPPED HOME
dialogues.text: A beat-up CORVAIR MONZA parks in front of a destitute hom

dialogues.speaker: IN MORALES LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: MRS. MORALES watches TV (NEWS about the first Manned Moon Orbit flight) in the dark with her HUSBAND, who is hidden his recliner. A lit cigarette in a crowded ashtray. RAMON MORALES (18), a young man with hard-knock looks and disappointed demeanor, drops off vials of prescription pi His mother smiles, but something inside her died years ag His father never turns. The soft glow of the television illuminates DISFIGUREMENTS too disturbing to look at.

dialogues.speaker: IN STEINBERG KITCHEN
dialogues.text: MRS. STEINBERG shucks peas as Alice crafts her own dress second-hand sewing machine.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: I said Spiderman. Not a spider man. Chuck, embarrassed to be dressed in a silly FOUR-ARMED SP COSTUME, beelines to the fridge to see what he can scaven it’s bare, save for some day-old bread and a carton of eg

dialogues.speaker: MRS. STEINBERG
dialogues.text: Spiders have eight legs-

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: He doesn’t- I gave you the comic book! He shows her a dynamic cover of Spiderman swinging betwee buildings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He’s a superhero, not a freak!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. STEINBERG
dialogues.text: Well, the superhero should be happy the Lord provided.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Aren't you too old to be trick or treating? Chuck spots a clown tapping outside the kitchen window.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Aren't you too ugly to be going on a date?-- Auggie’s here, gotta run. Alice lunges to throttle her little brother. Chuck swipes carton of eggs and runs off. Mom continues to shuck, unfa

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: “You've got to pick up every stitch... You've got to pick up every stitch... "

dialogues.speaker: ON STEINBERG BACKYARD
dialogues.text: Chuck exits hauling a BACKPACK, to meet a waiting Auggie

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: I thought you were gonna be Spiderman.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: (points at the arms) But the-

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Don’t worry about it. I got the goods. Let’s banana split.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: (leering through window) Is Alice getting dressed?

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Get your own sister, you giant perv. Off them hopping on their bikes and riding away --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “You've got to pick up every stitch. Mmhmmm..."

dialogues.speaker: IN MICHAELS BATHROOM
dialogues.text: Stella puts the finishing touches on her face paint and s back to inspect her work --

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “Must be the Season of the Witch.” Stella is unrecognizable. A near photo-realistic skull co her face. Her exquisite paint job is a labor of love. Confident -- she puts on her glasses and turns off the li

dialogues.speaker: TO TELL IN THE DARK
dialogues.text: As “Season of the Witch” fades out... darkness persists.. uncomfortable long moment... Long enough to be unnerving. And then SMASH TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bespectacled Skeleton, a Pierrot, and a Spider Man drag their pillowcases half-filled with candy and armaments. Chuck eyes a slow passing car as Auggie smokes a joint.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: «+. I’m just saying, if anything, a spider man should have eight arms, not four.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: At least I’m not a clown.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: I’m a Pierrot. A 17th century character from La Commedia Dell’arte, idiot stick. Stella sees porch lights beginning to turn off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He’s not gonna show.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: He'll show. Dick Breath does it every year and this time it’1ll be his last.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Well if he doesn’t, maybe next year you can carry the bag of shit. Chuck empties the last of his Good N’ Plentys into his mo

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: Do you even know what’s in those?

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: What are you now, The Man?

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: The same toxic chemicals that’s giving our troops Hodgkin's lymphoma and curdling the breast milk of the South Vietnamese.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: You’re crazy.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: Not crazy. Conscious. (passes joint to Stella) You sure you don’t want any? Cause you're creeping us out with this whole skeleton thing. She waves it off.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Yeah, pretty tragic considering it’s the anniversary your mom's death.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: (annoyed at Chuck) Dude. Chuck realizes his poor choice of words and backpedals --

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: I’m... sorry. I didn’t -- Stella goes solemn, but shirks it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s fine. Gimme that -- Stella grabs the joint. Before she takes a drag -- OS eng of a ‘68 Bonneville.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Shit! It’s Kurt --

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: (lowers clown mask) Cover your face, stupid. And hold out the bait. Chuck dons his disguise, acting as if this were some kind heist. INSIDE ‘68 BONNEVILLE Kurt laughs with his kind, throwing beer cans out the win IN THE BACKSEAT -- Alice is all done up for her date, wed between two Lettermans. She swats their unwanted advances

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (to Kurt, annoyed) You said we would have dinner. Kurt’s eyes narrow as he spots the backs of some trick-or treaters all alone.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: How ‘bout dessert? He hits the gas. His FLATTOP buddy cackles and leans out passenger window, prepping to snare the candy bag -- As they blow past, he RIPS the bag from Chuck’s hand. The all laugh. Flattop opens the pillowcase only to find --

dialogues.speaker: FLATTOP
dialogues.text: It’s full of old man undies! Enraged, Kurt slams on the brakes.

dialogues.speaker: ON STELLA AND FRIENDS
dialogues.text: They unload a SLEW OF EGGS and TOILET PAPER, pelting the

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Trick or treat, mother fuckers! ON ‘68 BONNEVILLE As the Bonneville takes on a barrage of egg yolk and tee Kurt angrily shifts the car into reverse, full speed.

dialogues.speaker: ON STELLA AND FRIENDS
dialogues.text: They hold their ground, not afraid to exhaust every bit o their stash. Payback for years of being picked on. Chuck proudly lights his BROWN PAPER BAG OF SHIT on fire.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And now for the Poup D’etat... As the Bonneville returns for a second pass, Chuck TOSSES - throwing it right into their window. INSIDE ‘68 BONNEVILLE The bag EXPLODES on Kurt’s lap. Alice SHRIEKS. He frantic swats the flames and manure, forgetting to hit the brakes The Bonneville surges backward, out of control --

dialogues.speaker: FLATTOP
dialogues.text: The brakes! The brakes!

dialogues.speaker: ON STELLA AND FRIENDS
dialogues.text: They beam in victory -- -- Only to see the Bonneville CRASH into a tree. Their sm drop, suddenly concerned by the inevitable fallout.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: Ah shit!

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Let’s cheese it! As they are running away -- ON CRASHED ‘68 BONNEVILLE Shit-stained Kurt and his cronies pile out of the car. Al sees her four-armed brother running away.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Chucky? Is that you?!

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: That’s your brother?! I’m gonna murder them!!  10. Kurt and his friends grab baseball bats and chase after. Alice stays with the car, her arms folded.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: Your sister went out with that dickhead?

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: So much for our cover. Let’s split up. Better odds only one of us dying.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: Meet up at The Gorge.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: Catch ‘ya later.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: Not if you catch a disease first. They splinter off, cutting through backyards. Kurt and the Lettermans stay as a pack, targeting Chuck.

dialogues.speaker: ON CHUCK
dialogues.text: Chuck sees the heat is on him and silently curses, all fo arms pumping in stride. He heads for the woods.

dialogues.speaker: ON KURT AND LETTERMANS
dialogues.text: Run into the woods, searching in all directions. Flattop finds -- The SPIDER MAN COSTUME. They fan out.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSKIRTS OF SUBURBS
dialogues.text: Shivering, Chuck exits the woods in his tightey-whiteys. catches his breath, then spots off in the distance --

dialogues.speaker: THE GORGE CINEMA
dialogues.text: A DRIVE-IN nestled in a natural basin on the waterfront. line of 60-era cars waiting to get inside.

dialogues.speaker: AT LINE OF CARS
dialogues.text: Chuck meets Stella and Auggie, ducking behind cars, tryin stay undetected by the Lettermans scanning the area.  11. They hide behind a CORVAIR MONZA, blaring “Little Green Apples”

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: You're in your underwear.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: I’m still not a clown. Stella shushes them. Then is surprised to see the trunk o the CORVAIR pop open. A voice from the driver --

dialogues.speaker: RAMON, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: You're acting like it’s your first time. She spots Ramon, vaguely recognizing him. Chuck and Auggi act first, hopping inside. Stella follows in after. Ramén pulls into the Drive-In, past a marquee that reads: “BORIS KARLOFF’S BLACK SABBATH”. Pays his ticket for one. Kurt and the Lettermans lose the scent and move on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE STARING, GRINNING FACE of a dead woman!! In gory technicolor. A smattering of cars idly face a towering outdoor screen showing the horror flick. Pipe organ swells through every hanging CAR WINDOW SPEAKER, as the small audience scarf popcorn or take part in the usual immoral behavior.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CORVAIR MONZA
dialogues.text: As Ramén watches the movie -- Chuck climbs out of the retractable back seat, putting on an oversized military t

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Mind if I borrow these fatigues I found in your trunk? I saw they were in a box marked for Goodwill.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: Have at it. Stella and Auggie pull themselves out, adrenaline still pumping through their veins.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: That was amazing.  12.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Did’ju see the look on their faces?

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: All I saw were your sister’s tits. Ramén looks at Auggie in his rear-view mirror, unsure of exactly he is looking at.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: «.. I’m a Pierrot. Stella pulls herself into the passenger seat. Wiping her paint off.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: Thanks. We owe you. (re: movie) Black Sabbath... a good one. Mario Bava- he’s real good-

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: Mario, what?

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: Bava. Italian. He’s done great movies- Black Sunday-

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: Should've been here last week when they played The Conqueror Worm.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: (Vincent Price impression) “Men sometimes have strange motives for the things they do.” Ram6én smiles upon meeting a kindred spirit.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: Ramén. Stella blushes, then turns her attention to the movie, pushing up her glasses to see better. Ramén feels dissed.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Her name is Stella. I’m Chuck, and this is Auggie. Stella sees the name ‘Morales’ on Chuck’s military attire

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: Hey, isn’t your dad that war hero who just moved in? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: STELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: People say he jumped on a grenade and lived. (morbidly fascinated) Does he like, still have his fingers and toes and stuff? Ramén is taken aback by her bluntness.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: Not all of them...

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: Forgive her. She’s strange. Chuck sees something out the window and ducks -

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Dick Breath alert. He’s coming in.

dialogues.speaker: AT CONCESSION STAND
dialogues.text: The banged-up Bonneville pulls into the drive-in. Kurt ge out and talks to a few Lettermans, motioning to the vicin Alice is offered a bucket of popcorn, but from her crosse arms, she clearly doesn’t want anything to do with this. They spread out to widen the search, peeking into cars.

dialogues.speaker: IN CORVAIR MONZA
dialogues.text: As Kurt and the Lettermans get closer --

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: Back in the trunk. Stella and Chuck are quick to take refuge but Auggie revo

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: No way that’s a trunk, at best it’s a large glove box.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: (handing over blanket) It’s your hide. Auggie hides under a blanket as the others go into the tr

dialogues.speaker: STELLA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Get your hand off my butt. I can’t control them.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: Ssh.  14. They quiet down and Ramén plays it cool. As they wait for Kurt to search the neighboring cars --

dialogues.speaker: RAMON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (discrete to Auggie) What’s up with weirdo bird? Auggie peeks out from under the blanket, keeping his voic low and his sentences short.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: Who, Stella? (beat) Her family moved here about ten years ago. Not long after, her mom was killed. She doesn’t like to talk about it, but everyone pretty much knows it was her dad that did it- Ramén looks shocked. Auggie back peddles --

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He didn’t kill her- Not on like purpose. He was drunk. And driving. He swears it was someone else but no one really buys it. Not even Stell. This sits with Ramén. He looks at the trunk through the r view mirror, suddenly empathetic. -- A RAP on the window startles them. Auggie hides. Ramén cranks down his window to see Kurt leering in.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: Soda and popcorn. Extra butter.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: (sneers, then) You wouldn’t happen to have seen a spider, a clown, or a skinny bitch? Auggie sees his clown shoes are peeking out. He tries to cover them but the blanket is too short.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: Now that you mention it... no. But you'll be the first to know. Kurt checks out Ramén’s car and laughs, knowing full well he’s being played. Behind him --  15. Lettermans gather, ready at his beckon call. Kurt motions them to hold off - he can handle it.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: You got a smart mouth, Amigo. I’1l let that slide. Besides -- (cutting to the bone) I feel bad for any war hero who has a hood for a son. Ramén grips the wheel, restraining his better instinct. KURT (CONT’D) (spots clown shoes) I see you, shit stain! Get outta the car! I bet that drunk’s girl is in there too!

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: Mind keeping it down? Everyone's trying to watch a movie.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: So you won’t get outta the car. See that, fellas? Mexicans aren't brown, they're yellow. Ram6én glances to see what he’s up against. It must be 5 He stays seated, knowing the smart play.

dialogues.speaker: KURT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I said - get out of the car. Spic. Ramén bolts out of the car, angrily pressing his forehead against Kurt’s, daring him to throw the first punch. Just as the Lettermans are about to pounce -- The flashing lights from a SHERIFF’S CRUISER. SHERIFF MILNER (50s), a once-strong lawman who’s grown we from the trade, steps out. He doesn’t suffer fools gladly

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF MILNER
dialogues.text: Leave it alone, Kurt. Kurt backs away with his hands up, staring daggers at Ram

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Sorry dad, we were just leaving.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: (returning to car) We are too, Sheriff.  16. The slight admission doesn’t go unnoticed by Kurt.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: You're all dead.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF MILNER
dialogues.text: Enough. Ram6én drives off. Chuck pops up in the rear windshield, flicking them off. Kurt looks to his father, like a sniveling tattle-tale. H father only returns a look of disappointment. SHERIFF MILNER (CONT’D) Go home. You smell like shit. Off Kurt’s disdain --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramén pulls out of the Drive-In. Stella and her friends g settled into their seats.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: Sorry you had to miss the movie.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I missed whatever you did to piss off that ape. (beat) You may wanna hold off going home. I take it he knows where you live?

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Maybe we can crash at your place?

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: I helped enough.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: We can lay low in the motel just outside of town?

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: And pay for it with what -- Abba Zaba and lollipops?

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: You know... (mischievous) The Bellows House is empty.  17. Auggie and Chuck share a cautious look --

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Yeah. They’re tearing it down to make way for the freeway later this week. No one’1l look for us there.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: No way. We all know what happens to kids who go into the Bellows House.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: What happens to the kids?

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: (giddy ) He doesn’t know. Ramén looks to Stella, hoping she will clear it up.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: Ever wanted to check out a haunted house?... Hang a left. Off Ramén’s growing curiosity, he takes the next turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Corvair Monza parks on a secluded dirt road. The gras has grown long. Years of neglect, or perhaps avoidance.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: (gazes out window) You really weren’t kidding... They step out of the car to see -- An unbuilt portion of a RAISED FREEWAY. A fractured monol of jagged rebar and cement. The two sides nearly touching Between the divide, on a hill... An imposing PURITAN MANOR on a sprawling, timeworn estate Black rotted wood. A pair of prodigious MASONRY CHIMNEYS. brittle facade is painted with shadows, consumed by rot, strangled by overgrown foliage.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: What better place to spend a Halloween Night. Muhahaha. Chuck cackles as he passes through a wrought-iron gate an crosses a cobblestone bridge over a dry creek bed.  18. Stella and Auggie slowly make their way. Ramén lingers.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: You coming? Intrigued, Ramén shuts his door and follows their lead.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: So who are the Bellows?

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: Some railway magnate who put Mill Valley on the map.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: It was just a settlement until they dammed the river, allowing this place to flourish. My mom says they were a pretty big deal back then. They pass a FAMILY PLOT. Every single tombstone marks a d in 1921. Ramén double checks to see if he saw that right, then races to catch up with the others.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: Lemme guess - something horrible happened to them in 1921? Stella and Ramén join Auggie onto the front porch where C BRICKS and WIRE line the house.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You sure we want to go in there? The place is lined to explode.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: Those demo bricks? Don’t sweat it, it’s not like they’re wired up. (stepping over) Better watch your step. They gingerly walk past the explosives.

dialogues.speaker: AT FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: Auggie slams his shoulder into the door a few times, when -- It swings open with Chuck inside, giving them a scare!

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: I got you!

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: You did not. How did’ju get inside?  19.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Through a window and I totally did.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: Now I’m gonna get you! Auggie chases Chuck --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Through the foyer and up the bannister stairs. The front door creaks open, welcoming Stella and Ramén in with the moonlight. They take in the surroundings with reserved wonderment and caution -- What once was a luxurious mansion has now been picked cle of any valuables and defaced over time: Torn, water-stain wallpaper. Missing floorboards. Broken and strewn article litter a floor already covered in layers of dust.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: So what happened to the Bellows? Stella runs her fingers down the wallpaper as she passes the halls, transfixed. Ramén hangs on her every word.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: They had a young daughter they never let out of the house. Sarah. As the story goes, they never allowed pictures of her either. Ram6én passes a PHOTOGRAPH of the BELLOWS FAMILY still hu the wall: A gaunt patriarch and matriarch with a thick gr ribbon around her neck, surrounded by sturdy young men.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: People say she was... different.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: How so?

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: Like, she didn’t look right. Had scoliosis and gigantism- or something. She was long and tall and sort of not right. But she had this gift, see? A milkman once said he saw her bring a dead rabbit back to life. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: STELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She could touch a dead flower and make it bloom- But that’s just the town’s usual gossip.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: Nothing usual about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car with LETTERMANS drive down the vacant road, passing Bellows front gates... and spot the parked CORVAIR MONZA. They share a grin, then speed off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Auggie reluctantly walks the halls in search of Chuck.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: Chuck?... Chuck? He finds a tear in the wallpaper, then takes pleasure in PEELING it for as long as he can, exposing rotted panelin An INTRUSION of COCKROACHES squeeze through an exposed cr Disgusted, he delicately tucks the wallpaper back.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know what you’re trying to do, you’re not going to scare me. Auggie cautiously moves ahead, swallowing his fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stella peruses bare bookshelves. A few moth-eaten tomes, nothing worth salvaging. As Ramén takes in the dreary roo she continues the Bellows story --

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: But Sarah was lonely. So she would write these scary stories. And kids would come from all around just to hear her read. To make them extra scary, she would write their names into them. Ramén sees a broken rocking chair next to cleft toys stre on the ground, and with her words, they take on new meani

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stella finds an ornate MUSIC BOX on the shelf. She winds up and it tinkers a CHILD-LIKE LULLABY. Her gaze drifts a she recollects the rest of the story.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But then the children started to go missing. Everyone knew it was her. (beat) When they couldn’t find them, they expected to find the bodies on this estate, but none were found. And when the police came to question Sarah - she disappeared. Never to be seen again.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: What happened to her?

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: No one knows. But a year later, in 1921, every member of her family died from bizarre and unexplained deaths. (beat) Some think it was the ghosts of the murdered children, others think it was Sarah herself, come back to punish her family for locking her up.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: What do you think? Stella takes a moment to choose her words carefully...

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: I think she just wanted to be like the other kids, but knew she could never be like them. As for the rest, I guess we’ll never know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck tiptoes through the decrepit remains of what once w an extravagant master bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Chuck? If you jump out at me, I’m going to punch you in the face. As Auggie’s footsteps are heard approaching, Chuck quickl climbs inside a large 18th century FRENCH ARMOIRE.  22.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE ARMOIRE
dialogues.text: Chuck stifles a laugh and hides inside. Creak - he peeks the open door. Auggie walks past the bedroom, unsuspectin AUGGIE (0.S.) (CONT’D) «+. Chuck? Chuck seals himself into the darkness, trying not to laug The sound of Auggie’s footsteps come back. Creak - Chuck cracks open the door again, only to see -- The entire bedroom is now vivid in color and texture. Exquisite antiquities adorn the walls and cover the room. if everything is suddenly restored to its 1921 condition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In startled awe, Chuck opens the armoire further to witne A GAUNT MATRIARCH with a wide GREEN RIBBON around her nec lies sick in bed, ominously staring back. Chuck GASPS and seals the armoire doors. Unable to catch breath. Heart pounding. Did he see what he thought he saw goes to peek again, when-- Auggie THROWS open the doors and YELLS! Scaring Chuck whi

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I totally got you back! Chuck holds his beating heart, regaining his wits as he s the master bedroom HAS RETURNED TO ITS DECREPIT STATE.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: The room -- It was new -- And there was a woman -- on the bed. A green ribbon around her neck.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: I know what you’re trying to do. I got you, and you can’t admit it.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: No, for real...

dialogues.speaker: YOU GUYS
dialogues.text: Chuck and Auggie share a look.  23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck and Auggie enter the expansive library to find Stel and Ramén - with an ALCARAZ RUG pulled back, standing ove A CELLAR HATCH hidden in the floor. The lines of where a used to lay framed around it. A SLIDING BOLT locks it.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: It doesn’t look like it’s ever been opened.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Maybe where they buried the bodies. Stella stares at the hatch - only one way to find out.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: BLACK. The sound of the bolt unlocks, and the hatch door opens. Moonlight floods in, revealing AN OLD STAIRCASE an the four teens framed within the hatch opening in wonderm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramén is brave enough to lead them down. He finds an OIL LAMP, lights a match to ignite it. A warm glow reveals -- A YOUNG GIRL’S BEDROOM kept preserved like a time capsule Fine, deco furnishings. A vanity sink and mirror. A quilt bed covered in worn dolls and dust.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: It’s Sarah’s bedroom...

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: What kind of family would lock up their own daughter?

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: This room's for a little kid. I thought Sarah was our age?

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: (catching on) She was... But her body was the size of an adult -- larger even... Auggie picks up an antique EFFANBEE DOLL.  24.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Her mind was simple -- maybe too simple. Stella sits behind the vanity, trying to imagine being in place. Personal items still perfectly placed. She puts on Sarah's slippers. A perfect fit. Disturbed, s quickly removes her feet.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is a real person. This isn’t fun anymore.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Let’s get outta here. As soon as they head toward the stairs --

dialogues.speaker: BOOM
dialogues.text: Auggie and Ramén try to open it!

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: Someone locked us in!

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: IT’S THE WITCH! WE’RE ALL GONNA

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: I can’t open it! But then - familiar LAUGHTER can be heard, coming from --

dialogues.speaker: IN THE LIBRARY
dialogues.text: It's Dick Breath, holding a baseball bat, drunk and savor Behind him is Alice, her comely dress wasted on the occas

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Kurt, they’re scared. Let them out.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Alice?! Is that you?!

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: I nearly shit my clown pants.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: You mean, Pierrot.  25.

dialogues.speaker: TEENS
dialogues.text: Let us out!/Not cool!/C’mon, Kurt!

dialogues.speaker: IN THE LIBRARY
dialogues.text: Alice shivers, not liking this place one bit.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Joke's over. If you don’t open it, I’m going to tell your father. Kurt’s sadistic laughter fades.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Now why would you do that? Alice is caught in his uncomfortable gaze.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: It’s my little brother. Kurt takes a pull from a flask.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Fine. Go ahead. Seeing he won’t help, Alice heaves open the hatch. But -- Kurt KICKS her down onto the others, then LOCKS the hatch

dialogues.speaker: KURT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you’re not putting out, you’re no better than the other trash!

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BASEMENT ROOM
dialogues.text: Alice falls into Auggie’s eager arms.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE LIBRARY
dialogues.text: Kurt wipes whisky from his sweaty grin.

dialogues.speaker: TEENS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You can’t leave us here!/They’re gonna blow up the house!

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Then I hope you find a way out.

dialogues.speaker: TEENS
dialogues.text: C'mon, jokes over!/Let us out!/ You’re subhuman, Kurt! Suddenly, TINKERING NOTES come back to life --  26. Kurt sees the MUSIC BOX sitting upon a derelict book shel He stares at the box, a bit spooked. He downs his flask, SMASHES it into pieces with his baseball bat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kurt coldly stumbles out from the house where a few of hi Lettermans have been guarding the exits.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Let’s bug outta here.

dialogues.speaker: FLATTOP
dialogues.text: Wha’ja do to them?

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Gave them what they deserve. Kurt and his cronies drive off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ram6én and Chuck pound on the locked hatch.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: Let us out!

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Yeah Kurt, don’t be a turd! Stella plops down on the bed - they could be there a whil

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: (to Chuck) Find something to bust this open. Ever the gentleman, Auggie helps Alice to her feet. She smooths out her skirt, only to find it’s ripped.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I worked so hard on this.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: It’s a nice dress. I mean, it still looks really good on you. Alice smiles --

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You're a Pierrot, right?  27. Auggie has a permanent grin. Life won’t get better than t As the others search for a way out... Stella feels someth under the mattress and pulls out -- THE BELLOWS BOOK. Considerable and weighty. Her fingers t warped leather, edges frayed. Smudges of dirt, faded bloo

dialogues.speaker: ALICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. She opens the tome, some frail pages stick together. She scans a few hand-written stories, enraptured. The others suspend their efforts to come see, intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s Sarah's book of scary stories. The one she’d read to the kids.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: That’s just town gossip--

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Or maybe they’re stories about how she murdered those kids? Stella flips through the pages, some covered with dark illustrations. She rests on a story called THE GREEN RIBB Before she can make sense of it -- A FAINT THUMPING is heard. Then an ominous GROANING. Grow LOUDER. Stella closes the book and puts it aside.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Kurt? Is that you? Within the walls, more CREAKING. Everyone eyes the ceilin and walls. Dust wafts. It’s as if the house is possessed.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: We disturbed the disturbed! Now we're gonna die!

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: (not buying it) It’s an old house - just built up water pressure --—  28. The vanity sink COUGHS UP gray water! Alice SCREAMS. Pipe RATTLE behind the CRACKING plastered walls. A pipe BURSTS from the wall, spraying Auggie!

dialogues.speaker: AAHH
dialogues.text: Auggie freaks out and charges up the stairs at full speed SLAMMING his giant frame into the hatch --

dialogues.speaker: IN THE LIBRARY
dialogues.text: He EXPLODES out of the hatch! They SCREAM, storming throu the fissuring mansion, trying to get out as fast as they A PIPE EXPLODES out of the wall - pouring out grey water. They run out SCREAMING!

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BASEMENT
dialogues.text: Stella’s the last one out. Feeling watched, she turns to IN THE MIRROR'S REFLECTION -- A pale, gaunt, eerily elong SARAH BELLOWS (16) sits on the bed wearing a soiled hazel gown. She has spindly limbs, a curved spine, and a simple sweet smile. Her bony fingers hold up her book.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH BELLOWS
dialogues.text: Youuu maaay beee theee neeext... Grey water pours out of her mouth. Stella clasps her mouth and turns, stifling a scream -- B SARAH ISN'T THERE. Only the book remains, as if calling h

dialogues.speaker: IN LIBRARY
dialogues.text: Stella surges out from the hatch with her pillowcase in h She fumbles to put on her glasses -- staring at the IMPRESSIVE CALAMITY SURROUNDING HER. The GROAN of bucklin wood sounds like a tortured soul. ... She follows her friends out. EXT. BELLOWS ESTATE —- CONTINUOUS They race out, only to be met by -- The flashing lights of Sheriff Milner and Deputy Hobbs’ s cars, screeching to a halt. Trigger barking. The cops get out of their cars and give chase.  29.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: It’s the fuzz! Let’s cheese it! Ram6n hightails it to his Corvair Monza.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: (hops in car) Get in -- They all pile into the vehicle already on the move. Once in, Ramén peels out. Sheriff Milner recognizes Ramén’s car. Deputy Hobbs runs after them on foot. It’s useless to follow.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY HOBBS
dialogues.text: Should we check out the house?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF MILNER
dialogues.text: Nah. I’1l be glad when they tear this eyesore down. He eyes the looming manor as Trigger whines, uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stella enters after the long night. Beer bottles decorate home where a mother’s absence is felt. She hear’s WHIMPER She passes her father’s room on the way to her bedroom -- Oren WEEPS next to his wife’s dress laid out on his bed. Stella feels little sympathy and quietly enters her room. INT. STELLA’S BEDROOM - MOMENTS LATER Stella is cocooned in a bedsheet tent, eating candy out h bag as she reads the Bellows Book by flashlight. CLOSE ON BOOK: Disturbing B/W illustrations from the stor “The Cat's Paw”, “Wait Till Martin Comes”, “The Wendigo”. She turns to the next chapter -- ‘HAROLD’. With it, a horrifying illustration of a scarecrow impaled on a pike.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: .--‘Harold’? Her hand smudges the ink. It’s still wet. Hmm.  30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kurt’s Bonneville drives onto his family’s sprawling prop with a FARM HOUSE and BARN in the back. Distant CORNFIELD Drunk, he staggers out of his car and chucks his beer can a SCARECROW made from old sacks and stuffed with straw.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Eat shit, Harold. ‘Harold’ is pelted in its burlap face, a crooked scowl permanently stitched on. A pile of spent beer cans below. Kurt stumbles to his house -- he’s startled by MRS. MILNE barking from the front door in a robe and sour face.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILNER
dialogues.text: It’s late.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: It’s Halloween.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILNER
dialogues.text: You were supposed to feed the chickens.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: It’s Brett’s turn.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILNER
dialogues.text: Do it before your father gets home. He flippantly saunters toward the barn, kicking a chicken fails to notice - the pole where Harold was hung is now b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kurt sets down a tin bucket filled with water. CLOSE ON: The WATER BUCKET. As the surface of the water stills. the faint REFLECTION OF SARAH BELLOWS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bag of CHICKEN FEED is RIPPED open. Kurt haphazardly sp some on top of the hungry chickens gathering at his feet.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Eat up. Get nice and fat. He gets disturbed at the carcass of a dead chicken, pecke death by its own.  31. The wind picks up outside, creating a faint HOWLING throu the slats in the barn walls. The CAWING of crows. Kurt perks up. Thinking it was nothing, he returns to fee the chickens when he sees -- A FIGURE standing between the barn doors. Kurt squints to -- It’s the scarecrow standing upright. HAROLD takes an unnatural step forward, jerky. Kurt nearl trips over the chickens.

dialogues.speaker: KURT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The hell?! -- The chickens peck at Kurt’s feet, but he doesn’t notice. fixed on the WALKING MAN OF HAY before him. Harold LURCHES closer. Kurt runs -- enters...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MAZE of stables. He runs- desperate- scared- He hides, panting. A creak is heard- he peeks-— Harold is coming. Kurt sprints. Scared, he falls onto his ass. Right next t PITCHFORK.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Whoever’s in there, you’re gonna pay for this! Kurt WHACKS Harold with the pitchfork! The scarecrow FALL LIMP to the ground with a GRUNT. He stands over the scarecrow, trying to see who is hiding behind the hay. But there is no one, only a sinking feeli Harold REACHES for Kurt, who CRIES OUT while violently STABBING the scarecrow with the pitchfork. RIPPING out it straw intestines, BEATING the living hay out of it. Harold is completely TORN TO PIECES. Kurt stands over it, heaving, victorious -- but confused to what this thing is.  32.

dialogues.speaker: KURT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mom?! MOM?!-- He CHOKES on something. Airway obstructed. He COUGHS up s hay, struggling for air. He tries to call for help, but n words come out -- only hay. EXT. BARN - MILNER FARMSTEAD —- CONTINUOUS Kurt charges out of the barn, turning blue with asphyxiat He runs through the cornfield -- His eyes bulge as he witnesses hay coming out of his slee and pants. Straw lengthens from his ears, nose and eyes. trembles to find the skin on his hand drying, like burlap He falls as straw grows from every part of him. He reache out to his home and releases a final muffled scream.. Only for hay to silently explode from his mouth! And he stops- frozen in place- standing in the cornfield. A scarecrow.

dialogues.speaker: SMASH TO BLACK
dialogues.text: EXT. MILL VALLEY HIGH SCHOOL —- NEXT MORNING All is quiet. A JANITOR rides a LAWN MOWER over the grass An UPBEAT song begins. A real sugar-pop earworm.

dialogues.speaker: DISK JOCKEY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: It’s nasty November. The time when both sides of the political aisle come together to bury each other in the mud. SEQUENCE OF SHOTS of SCHOOL STARTING: The parking lot is of students showing off their cars, the Principal stands guard by his Cadillac, a Recruiter flirts with two hippie chicks, black students play frisbee, etc.

dialogues.speaker: DISK JOCKEY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Don’t believe anything you hear, Mill Valley. To help separate truth from fiction, here’s John Fred & His Playboys with ‘Judy in Disguise’.  33. A school bell rings as students loiter around the school. Stella races to school, clutching the Bellows Book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stella slams Chuck and Auggie’s locker before it can open

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: You’1ll never guess what I read.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: You took the book?

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Why would you take the book?!

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: Last night... I saw something in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: I think it was... her.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: Halloween’s over. Can I please have 364 days of not dealing with your bullshit?

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: No, I saw something too. When I was hiding. There was this woman, with a green ribbon around her neck.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: And when I opened the book last night, there was this new chapter, and the ink was wet. She opens the book to “Harold”.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Kurt's name was in it.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: (feigning scared) Oh my god. Kurt Dipplestine? Or maybe Kurt Rogers? I hope she wasn’t a fan of Kurt Douglas. (dismissive) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Even Dick Breath’s name is popular. It’s probably just a coincidence. Auggie opens the locker to grab his book, uninterested. Stella flips through the pages, hoping to make a case --

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: But there are more chapters with no stories. Five of them. Each one unwritten...

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: W-what do you mean, unwritten?

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: Spooky. Sarah’s just as lazy as us. Alice and Ramén approach with books in hand.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: Did anyone notice that asshole didn’t have the balls to show? Alice notices the SCARECROW ILLUSTRATION in the Bellows B

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Creepy drawing. Looks just like the scarecrow on Kurt’s farm. Stella and her friends share a look.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: You mean Kurt. As in Kurt Milner. That scarecrow is on Kurt Milner’s farm?

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: (suddenly intrigued) What exactly is in that story? Off their troubled looks -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ram6én raps on the screen door as Alice, Stella, Chuck an Auggie wait on the porch. After no answer, he knocks agai Chuck turns and catches sight of something OFF SCREEN.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Guys?... Guys look. They follow Chuck’s gaze to find -  35. The SCARECROW -- only now it’s dressed in Kurt’s clothes. crooked scowl permanently stitched to a burlap face.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Isn’t that what he was wearing last night? The front door SWINGS OPEN, startling them.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILNER
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Milner reads ‘Harold’, unsure of what to make of it. six-year-old, BRETT, clings to her arm. The teens anxiously sit on the sofa, sipping tea. Except Ramén, who stands -- put off by a nearby framed photo of Sheriff Milner. Mrs. Milner closes the Bellows Book and takes a moment.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILNER
dialogues.text: And you wrote this? Chuck is about to explain, but Auggie takes this one.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: We just haven’t seen him around school, and were wondering if your husband or yourself had seen anything... unusual? Mrs. Milner gives a sour look, then --

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILNER
dialogues.text: Let me call Roy. Stay here. She leaves and her young son follows, attached at the hip soon as they are gone, Ramén tips down the Sheriff's phot

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: She doesn’t believe us.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: I don’t even know if I believe us. Chuck catches sight of Stella staring at the coffee table

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: What?  36.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: (re: tea cups; dread) There’s five of them...

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Yeah, five teacups. You can count --

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: No... five cups. Five of us. Five chapters left. They share a look, pondering the implication.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What if there’s a story for each of our names? What if what happened to Kurt, is going to happen to us? Auggie motions for her to quiet down. Ram6én watches Mrs. Milner in the KITCHEN, quietly talkin the phone. The mother gives a suspicious look back. INT. KITCHEN - MILNER FARMSTEAD — CONTINUOUS Mrs. Milner turns her back to them, discreetly talking:

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILNER
dialogues.text: Yes, I know. And that young Mexican that picked a fight with Kurt at the Drive-In is here too. (beat) Okay. I’1ll keep them here. She hangs up, then gives her youngest an encouraging smil She grabs the tea pot and puts on a fake smile. MRS. MILNER (CONT’D) Refill anyone? She enters into AN EMPTY ROOM. They’ve split.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sheriff's cruiser pulls up as he’s met by Mrs. Milner

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILNER
dialogues.text: They’re gone. (hopeful) Any word from Kurt?  37.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF MILNER
dialogues.text: Still nothing. He glances at Brett, chucking rocks at a murder of crows gathering at the scarecrow, and thinks nothing of it.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILNER
dialogues.text: They were acting strange. And that odd Michael’s girl wrote a story.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF MILNER
dialogues.text: A story? -- He can hardly hear himself over the cawing of crows. SHERIFF MILNER (CONT’D) Stop minding the crows, Brett. Brett stops throwing rocks. CLOSE ON SCARECROW: The crows keep picking SINEWY BITS of flesh from under the scarecrows burlap skin. BACK ON the parents, none the wiser.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILNER
dialogues.text: This isn’t like him, Roy.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF MILNER
dialogues.text: Don’t worry. I’1l find our boy.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: A FIRE BURNS in a tilled area, fueled by dried corn husks

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ram6n stands with the others circled around the fire, bur hot. Stella stares into the flames, holding the Bellows B

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: I don’t wanna say it - but maybe it’s good that he’s gone.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: What do we tell people if they ask?

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: Doesn’t matter what you say. Look at us - some freaks, some geeks, and a Mexican. They'll never believe a word. (pointed finger) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: RAMON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No one says anything about last night. The group nods, except for Alice. Auggie looks to her, sympathetic. She finally agrees.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: What if the fuzz came cause he ratted on us? They’1l know we were with him...

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I was on a date. They’1l think I had something to do with it.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: It wasn’t us. It was the book. And it’s all over. Stella tossing the Book into the fire. They watch it burn CLOSE ON: The Book’s pages curl up in flames, its leather bubbles and chars. Cursed or not, it’s destroyed.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: INT. STELLA’S BEDROOM - FLASHBACK CLOSE ON: YOUNG STELLA (6) reads a book in her mother’s l The bedroom is pink. The light is dreamy. A nostalgic mem

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG STELLA
dialogues.text: (learning to read) “The tiger din... dind...”

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: (helping) “Didn't”.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG STELLA
dialogues.text: “Didn't just eat one bun. He ate all of the buns... on the dish.”

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: (turning page) Good, Stella. Stella looks up, though we never see her mother’s face.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG STELLA
dialogues.text: No more reading.  39.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Don’t you want to know how the story ends? She shakes her head with a mischievous grin.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ll help you.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA AND MOTHER
dialogues.text: “And then he ate all the biscuits.” INT. STELLA’S BEDROOM —- MORNING - PRESENT Stella wakes up in her own bed. Her eyes still tired. She wipes the sleep from them, then spots a handwritten N from her father on the lamp shade that begins ‘STELLA’. Off her reading the note --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stella rides to a construction site where they are buildi FREEWAY, her textbooks strapped to the back of her bike. She ducks as she passes through steel and cement spires.

dialogues.speaker: UNDER THE OVERPASS
dialogues.text: Stella finds her father laying a network of rebar.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: Got your note -- Oren removes his work gloves and goggles. Over the noise, gestures to his FOREMAN he’s going to take five.

dialogues.speaker: OREN
dialogues.text: Good news - They found something for me over in Troutdale. They’re looking for a new supervisor --

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: OREN
dialogues.text: C'mon, Stell. You know we’ve been looking for our break.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: We? You mean, you.  40.

dialogues.speaker: OREN
dialogues.text: You'll make new friends --

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: Mom chose this place. (tempers her words) How am I supposed to visit her? Or are you going to drive? God knows putting you behind the wheel--

dialogues.speaker: OREN
dialogues.text: We need to leave this place. Leave it behind. Start over. Hurt and confused, Stella walks away with her bike.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: We can’t start over. You did that. Her father is pained to see her leave. Stella hops onto her bike, then notices something on the that stops her cold -- The BELLOWS BOOK atop her schoolbooks, in pristine condit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stella rides her bike- Fast. She goes by the plaza, where the FAMILIES of grieving par witness the flag being lowered half-mast. It’s a small ceremony for the fallen sons. Folded flags are being hand-delivered to the parents by a OFFICER IN UNIFORM and white gloves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stella urgently raps on Ramén’s front door. He opens it t find her clutching the Bellows Book.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: «--It’s back. She allows herself in.  41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is bare with moving boxes stacked about. Ramon inspects the Book in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: How is this possible? Frightened, Stella shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: There’s a new story. With Chuck’s name in it.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: Do you want me to drive?

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: There’s no time. I need your phone. As Stella barges in, Ramén opens the Book to see for hims

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: Kitchen. CLOSE ON BOOK: The next story is entitled “The Big Toe”. Ram6n lifts his thumb from the page to find INK PRINT.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The ink’s still wet...

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: (defensive) I didn’t write it.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: I didn’t say you did. Stella passes the FAMILY ROOM, she catches a glimpse of - RAMON’S FATHER. His ear is burned off. His face disfigure He meets Stella’s glance as she has trouble looking away. Then, she quickly moves on.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: As Stella rushes to dial Chuck’s number, Ramén quickly re the ‘The Big Toe’.  42.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “One day, Mrs. Steinberg was digging in her garden, when she saw a big toe sticking out of the ground. She tried to pick it up but it was stuck. So she pulled as hard as she could and it came off in her hand..." (confused) What the hell is this? This story is gross. Stella gets a busy signal ringing on the other end.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: Keep reading. She hangs up and tries again.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on, pick up.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: (reading) “'That looks like a nice piece of meat', she said. ‘I'll put it in the loaf and we'll have it for... dinner'"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck cradles the phone on his shoulder, talking to his mother on the other end, while trying to find something t eat in the kitchen. Shelves are bare.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: (into phone) What leftovers, ma? I don’t see anything. Chuck opens the fridge to discover -- a gleaming MEATLOAF

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into phone) Mmm. My favorite. Thanks. I’1l see you when you get home. Chuck hangs up, and moves the meatloaf to the counter.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (licking lips) Meat is back on the table.  43. He fetches a fork and plunges it into the moist loaf. To trained eye, we see what looks like a HUMAN TOE baked in. Starving, Chuck mows down. Mashing sinewy meat in his mou The kitchen phone rings. He stuffs in another mouthful be grabbing the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into phone) What is it now. -- I’m eating, ma.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Stella?

dialogues.speaker: STELLA, (PHONE)
dialogues.text: DON’T EAT ANYTHING!

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Why? I’m starving. My mom made a --

dialogues.speaker: STELLA, (PHONE)
dialogues.text: You're in the next story. Listen to me. Don’t eat the meat.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? We got rid of the book.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA, (PHONE)
dialogues.text: DON’T EAT THE MEAT! Chuck’s chewing slows as he eyes the loaf of minced meat. bites on something hard, then pulls from his mouth... A large, rotted human TOE NAIL.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA, (PHONE)
dialogues.text: Chuck?... CHUCK?! Chuck gags, trying not to hurl. He flushes his mouth unde the faucet, then gets back on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: ...What happens in my story?

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: (to Ramén) What happens next?

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: Uh... He eats the toe, and “That’s when Charles heard a voice, saying ‘You may be the next.’”

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: A voice says ‘You may be the next.’

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON CHUCK, TENSE
dialogues.text: He looks around the kitchen. Waiting. Listening. He peeks around the corner - the house is empty. Silent.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: It’s quiet... There’s no voice. I’m the only one here. He pokes his fork to dig through the meatloaf and instant recognizes a SEVERED EAR. He recoils, pushing it away.

dialogues.speaker: ON STELLA AND RAMON
dialogues.text: Ramén holds the book out to Stella to finish reading:

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: We're reading it right here. ‘Then the voice grew louder...’ (louder) “YOU MAY BE THE NEXT!”

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON
dialogues.text: Paranoid, Chuck rips open the blinds, half-expecting to s someone... but nothing.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: I’M ALL ALONE! THERE’S NO VOICE...

dialogues.speaker: ON STELLA AND RAMON
dialogues.text: It dons on Stella. She looks to Ramén, horrified --

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: --. It’s me. (to Ramén; urgent) How does it end?  45.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: Nothing. That’s it.

dialogues.speaker: ON CHUCK
dialogues.text: Huddled in a dark corner, eyeing his empty house.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: That’s it? That’s not an ending.

dialogues.speaker: WHAT KIND OF ENDING IS THAT
dialogues.text: From out of the shadows behind him -- SARAH BELLOWS lurches out at him! Her elongated soured li reaching from the shadows. He SCREAMS!!

dialogues.speaker: ON STELLA AND RAMON
dialogues.text: They hear Chuck’s SCREAM. Then silence, as - CHUCK’S PHONE Falls, dangling on its cord, knocking against the fridge.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: Chuck?!... CHUCK?!! No response. Then -—

dialogues.speaker: SARAH BELLOWS, (PHONE)
dialogues.text: «.. Steeelllaaa... Stella SLAMS the phone onto its wall unit, horror-struck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The parking lot of the drive-in theater is vast and empty except for a Corvair Monza and two bikes parked outside t Snack Shack. A beat up Chrysler crosses the abandoned lot

dialogues.speaker: AT SNACK SHACK
dialogues.text: Stella sits on the counter, despondent. Auggie stares at ice melting in his coke. Ramon leans his head against a w They watch Alice coming with a vengeance --

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Where is that little shit? He was supposed to be home for dinner. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ALICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Next time he thinks about sleeping over without telling our parents... She notices under Stella’s glasses, eyes raw from crying.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ..-Where’s my brother?

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: (afraid to ask) What did you have for dinner?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: We all had Spamloaf, why?

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: (gags) Oh god. The others recoil. Alice looks lost.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: He wasn’t with us. Reluctant, Auggie holds up the Bellows Book.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: The Book came back.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: It was my fault. We should’ve never gone into that house. Alice can’t believe it, shaking her head.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: No... we watched it burn.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: There was a new story.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: What story?! Auggie isn’t sure if he should show her, but Alice rips i from his grasp. Quickly finding the page and skimming.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: I tried to warn him... but every thing I said only made it worse.  47.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: The ending never told us what happened. We were hoping he was with you. Alice GAGS, repulsed at what she’s reading. She VOMITS in trash bin. Unable to truly comfort her, Auggie rubs her b

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: I heard her. She knows our names.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: Four stories left. Four of us.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Jesus. My brother just died and now this is gonna happen to us?!

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: First Kurt... now Chuck... (angered) We have to stop her. We have to do something.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: Do what?! We’ve already burned it!

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know but I sure as hell ain’t gonna sit around and wait for my story to be written! There’s gotta be someway to stop a witch.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: She's not a witch. It’s a curse!

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: Forgive me! A cursed witch --

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: So what? We wait around to see which of our names come next?

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: (mind races) What about the titles. To our stories. Maybe they’re clues...

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: The next story is ‘The Red Spot’... Does that mean anything to anyone? They share blank glances. A few shrug.  48.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Red Spot? That could be anything.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: What about the rest of them?

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: The next ones are “The Dream", “Me Tie Dough-ty Walker”...

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: Me Tie what? What kinda title is that?

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: .-- And the last chapter, “The Haunted House”. They all share a knowing look.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: Well we all know where that is.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: No way am I going back. Ramon smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full speed. Ramon drives like a demon. The gang sits, ten

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: (to Alice) If she wants to pick us off one by one, we need to get ahead of it. Instead of waiting for the next story to happen...

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: (finishing sentence) «+. We see how everything ends.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: There’s gotta be answers... Ramon barely avoids a collision.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Hey, Bullit, watch it.  49.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Corvair Monza parks in front of the gate leading to t Bellow’s Estate. As soon as they get out -- KRA-KOOOOM!!! The explosives go off atop the hill, releas a shower of wood, plaster and bricks. It’s ear-shattering Surprised, they quickly race up the long driveway --

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: No no no no noooo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stella, Ramén, Auggie and Alice stand before what's left the Bellows Mansion. A backhoe compresses down on a remai awning until it buckles. Wood splinters. Glass breaks. A gaping hole left in the dead carcass of a house.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: There goes the answers. Bulldozers plow debris, while a FOREMAN wears a hard hat, directing a digger and crane raising a dug up COFFIN.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Careful... careful... He unshackles it. Then gives the hand signal for the cran operator to fetch the next one. He notices the teens --

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You shouldn't be here. This is no place for kids. Stella is mesmerized by the crew raising another casket. it pans over heads, the worm-eaten coffin crumbles, pryin loose from its binds --

dialogues.speaker: WATCH OUT
dialogues.text: The coffin falls. A Worker dives out of the way just as t casket shatters to pieces on the ground, releasing - A CORPSE, dressed in a rotten white gown and a wide GREEN RIBBON around her neck. The skull rolls off, detaching fr the body. It was the ribbon holding it on. Alice screams.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: The green ribbon -- the woman Chuck saw.  50.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: How? She’s been dead over 40 years.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: You gotta get outta here. This is no place for kids. The Foreman returns to his crew as they solemnly head bac down the long driveway.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Is there another Haunted House? Why would the last chapter say ‘Haunted House’ if it’s gone?

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: You said Sarah vanished. To where? (mind racing) Maybe if we find her remains, we can lay them to rest... give her a proper burial.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: This isn’t a movie, dork. A glint of something OS catches Stella’s eye. Then the TINKERING of a familiar childlike-melody.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I didn’t say it was. Stella lowers to some construction debris where sits the MUSIC BOX that was destroyed, rebuilt in perfect order. Stella picks it up, intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Then let’s start digging. How ‘bout this? I’ll take these 100 acres. You got those 100 acres. I’m sure Alice is good with a shovel.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You don’t need to be a dick about it. I’m just trying to help.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Help? I’m trying to live. She studies the Music Box. Stella turns it over and finds is engraved with the name -- “ELOISE W”.  51.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: You say they died 40 years ago?

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Why?

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: Maybe there was someone in that house that’s still alive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Corvair Monza pulls into the Sunnyhaven Nursing Home parking lot that looks neither sunny nor a haven.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: There’s two places dead people go to in this town. The cemetery, and Sunnyhaven.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: The caretaker told me they didn’t have anyone named Eloise, but they do have a LouLou Walker that fits the bill. They exit the car, taking in the dreary nursing home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three old bedridden elderly men share a room with only on window. A CHEERFUL MAN rests closest to the window, while CANTANKEROUS BED MATES are not privileged to enjoy the vi

dialogues.speaker: CANTANKEROUS BED MATE
dialogues.text: How does it look out there today, George?

dialogues.speaker: CANTANKEROUS BED MATE
dialogues.text: What do you see?

dialogues.speaker: CHEERFUL MAN
dialogues.text: The flowers have bloomed. Oh, and that voluptuous woman has returned. A CARETAKER guides Stella and her friends past their room but as their vantage point pivots, they see the view from window IS MERELY A BRICK WALL. George gives them a dead stare and a hollow smile, hoping they will keep his secret. They move on into --  52.

dialogues.speaker: THE SUN ROOM
dialogues.text: Frail elderly are hunched over in wheelchairs parked alon the walls, holding onto what little life they have left. The Caretaker points Stella and her friends toward an Afr American woman in her late 70s, staring out a musty stain glass window.

dialogues.speaker: CARETAKER
dialogues.text: That’s LouLou. Don’t expect to get much out of her. They approach LOULOU and see her milky cataract eyes star at nothing in particular.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: Eloise Walker? She only trembles, crippled by late-stage Parkinson's.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: LouLou Walker? Can you hear us?

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: Why are we wasting time -- Stella winds the Music Box and lets it play. The child-li melody puts a sweet smile on LouLou --

dialogues.speaker: LOULOU
dialogues.text: ... You May Be the Next. Stella and Ramén share a look, recognizing those words.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: Why did you say that?

dialogues.speaker: LOULOU
dialogues.text: It’s a song, sweetheart. (murmurs song) ‘The worms crawl in, the worms crawl out, the worms play pinochle on your snout...’

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: You knew Sarah, didn’t you?

dialogues.speaker: LOULOU
dialogues.text: I used to watch over that family. How those kids loved to hear her scary stories. (fondly recollects) She had a gift... to fix things. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: LOULOU, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Even helped me see for a bit. They told her she was a monster. But I thought she was a sight. They share a look, mystified. But Alice loses her patienc

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Then why is she torturing us? What did we ever do to her-- Stella calms Alice, then takes a gentler approach.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: We have her book. And she’s still writing stories. Why?

dialogues.speaker: LOULOU
dialogues.text: Stories hurt. Stories heal. If all you know is hatred, it can make you go mad. Angry for so long. (singing) ‘They'll eat your ears, they'll eat your nose, they'll eat the jelly between your toes...’

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: Do you know what happened to the kids? The kids that she murdered?

dialogues.speaker: LOULOU
dialogues.text: I can still hear them laughing... (shakes head) She could never do those things. The Bellows never done right to that sweet girl.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: She didn’t hurt the kids...

dialogues.speaker: LOULOU
dialogues.text: You sound just like your mother asking those questions. Stella grows cold -- what did she just say?

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: My mother? She was here?

dialogues.speaker: LOULOU
dialogues.text: ‘Don't ever laugh as the hearse goes by, for you may be the next to... (die).’ The music box ends and LouLou drifts off, lost in thought  54.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: Why was she here? How do you know my mother? Is this your music box? Stella desperately winds the music box again to let it pl

dialogues.speaker: STELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You talked to my mother. When? When did you talk to her? LouLou? Stella tries to shake her awake, but she doesn’t respond.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: Ease up.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: LouLou? Talk to me. The caretaker intervenes.

dialogues.speaker: CARETAKER
dialogues.text: That’s enough. I need you to leave. Off their concern --

dialogues.speaker: DISK JOCKEY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: More grim news...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Residents of Mill Valley walk the fields, ten feet apart, waving flashlights. It’s a search party.

dialogues.speaker: DISK JOCKEY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: On the heels of the missing persons report out for the Sheriff’s son, we have another disappearance. Condolences to the Steinbergs... I pray we can find their son Charlie. Alice is with her parents, biting her lip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Corvair Monza is parked outside the PUBLIC LIBRARY. A acropolis built in a time when Mill Valley once had promi

dialogues.speaker: DISK JOCKEY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: If anyone has any information, please contact local authorities. Look at that, my phone lines are already blowing up...  55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The library is mostly empty. Orb lights softly illuminate labyrinth of books. SEQUENCE OF SHOTS as they research anything and everything that can shed light on things:

dialogues.speaker: MALE CALLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Isn’t it obvious? It’s a prank. Just some kids, making trouble.

dialogues.speaker: DISK JOCKEY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We all have our opinions. But to change the mood, here’s The Dock of the Bay! The song starts- giving place to a montage-- --A STACK OF BOOKS HIT a table, “Oregon Territory Rights 1928” “Mill Valley Town and Vital Records Vol. 1,” --“Registry of Historic Places,” etc. Auggie drops them o for -- -- Stella, already scouring a stack of old periodicals. S pulls out a front page that has photos of nine children, older than ten. “Children continue to vanish. Parents dem blood,” is the headline. She starts scribbling each child’s name onto a note pad.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE CALLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Our children are paying for our sins. All of this free love. This race mixing. We need an American Independent, like George Wallace -- A venerable LIBRARIAN sorts books back onto shelves, keep a judgmental eye on Ramon, fervently reading in the aisle

dialogues.speaker: DISK JOCKEY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is still the real world, is it not? All I know is this is a time to come together, not apart. Ram6én studies a county map. He traces the Yamhill River his finger, until it intersects with the Bellows Rail Yar Further downstream is the heart of Mill Valley. Ram6én catches the Librarian’s stare, then stares back. S moves on. Ramén continues to search for answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stella cross references names as Ramén reads the Bellows Book, while Auggie looks for more research material.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: The name in the Green Ribbon is... is... gimme a minute. Stella looks up, knowing the answer already.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: Dolores.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: (seeing name, then) How did you --

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: Sarah's mother. The woman with the green ribbon around her neck.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: Every member of her family, they are all in this book.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: Even weirder, anyone that spent considerable time with them died of either a strange accident or unnatural causes... (holds up obituary) The detective who searched inside their house? Died of a heart attack in his apartment three years ago... found eaten by his cats, including his beloved Martin.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: Nothing unnatural about that.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: And all the deaths are in like, chronological order. Except the kids she murdered, who should be in the front of the book... (looking through notes) They aren’t in any of the chapters. Their names don’t appear anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: (struggling to track) Wait. If everyone died who went in that house, how did LouLou survive?  57.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. You heard her, Sarah loved her.

dialogues.speaker: RAMON
dialogues.text: Maybe the kids died before she became a cursed witch --

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: Or maybe she never murdered them in the first place. Ramén raises an eyebrow - that is quite the allegation. Auggie unloads another stack of periodicals.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
